member.name: T:System.Threading.Collections.ConcurrentStack`1
member.summary:
A stack that uses CAS operations internally to maintain thread-safety in a lock-free manner. Attempting to push or pop concurrently from the stack will not trigger waiting, although some optimistic concurrency and retry is used, possibly leading to lack of fairness and/or livelock. The stack uses spinning and backoff to add some randomization, in hopes of statistically decreasing the possibility of livelock.
Note that we currently allocate a new node on every push. This avoids having to worry about potential ABA issues, since the CLR GC ensures that a memory address cannot be reused before all references to it have died.
member.typeparam: The type of elements the stack will hold.

member.name: M:System.Threading.Collections.ConcurrentStack`1.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs a new empty stack.

member.summary: Constructs a new stack which has been initialized with the contents of the provided collection.
member.param: The collection whose contents are to be copied.

member.name: M:System.Threading.Collections.ConcurrentStack`1.Clear
member.summary: Clears the contents of the stack in a thread safe and lock free manner.

member.name: M:System.Threading.Collections.ConcurrentStack`1.CopyTo(System.Array,System.Int32)
member.summary: Copies the contents of the stack to an array. This conceptually takes a copy of the stack at a point in time, and so it clearly may be out-of-date by the time the function returns.
member.param: The array (of T[] or an assignable type) into which the stack's contents will be copied.
The index at which the copied elements will begin.
member.exception: If the array's type is incompatible with T.
If a multi-dimensional array is supplied.
If the array's lower bound is non-zero.
If there is insufficient space in the array.
If index is not within range.

member.name: M:System.Threading.Collections.ConcurrentStack`1.Push(`0)
member.summary: Pushes a node onto the front of the stack thread-safely. Internally, this simply swaps the current head pointer using a (thread safe) CAS operation to accomplish lock freedom. If the CAS fails, we add some back off to statistically decrease contention at the head, and then go back around and retry.
member.param: The element to push.

member.name: M:System.Threading.Collections.ConcurrentStack`1.TryPeek(`0@)
member.summary: Peeks at the head of the stack and returns its value without modifying the stack. This is done thread-safely, although because the contents are not modified there is no guarantee that multiple threads will not see the same element or that the list has not been modified already.
member.param: The element seen at the head of the stack.
member.returns: True if the stack was non-empty, false otherwise.

member.name: M:System.Threading.Collections.ConcurrentStack`1.TryPop(`0@)
member.summary: Tries to pop the node from the front of the stack. Internally, this is done thread-safely and uses a CAS operation to accomplish lock freedom.
member.param: The element popped from the stack, or default(T) if empty.
member.returns: True if an element was popped, false if the stack was empty.

member.name: M:System.Threading.Collections.ConcurrentStack`1.ToArray
member.summary: Returns an array containing a snapshot of the stack's contents.
member.returns: An array of the stack's contents.

member.name: M:System.Threading.Collections.ConcurrentStack`1.ToList
member.summary: Returns a list containing a snapshot of the stack's contents.
member.returns: A list of the stack's contents.

member.name: M:System.Threading.Collections.ConcurrentStack`1.GetEnumerator
member.summary: Returns an enumerator for the stack. This effectively takes a snapshot of the stack's contents at the time of the call, i.e. subsequent modifications (pushes or pops) will not be reflected in the enumerator's contents.
member.returns: An enumerator for the stack.

member.name: P:System.Threading.Collections.ConcurrentStack`1.IsEmpty
member.summary: Checks whether the stack is empty. Clearly the answer may be out of date even prior to the function returning (i.e. if another thread concurrently adds to the stack). It does guarantee, however, that, if another thread does not mutate the stack, a subsequent call to TryPop will return true -- i.e. it will also read the stack as non-empty.

member.name: P:System.Threading.Collections.ConcurrentStack`1.Count
member.summary: Counts the number of entries in the stack. This is an O(n) operation. The answer may be out of date before returning, but guarantees to return a count that was once valid. Conceptually, the implementation snaps a copy of the list and then counts the entries, though physically this is not what actually happens.

member.name: P:System.Threading.Collections.ConcurrentStack`1.System#Collections#ICollection#IsSynchronized
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether access to this collection is synchronized. Always returns false. The reason is subtle. While access is in face thread safe, it's not the case that locking on the SyncRoot would have prevented concurrent pushes and pops, as this property would typically indicate; that's because we internally use CAS operations vs. true locks.

member.name: P:System.Threading.Collections.ConcurrentStack`1.System#Collections#ICollection#SyncRoot
member.summary: Retrieves an object that can be used to synchronize access to the collection. Always returns null, since this is not synchronized in the classic sense.

member.name: T:System.Threading.CountdownEvent
member.summary:
CountdownEvent is a simple synchronization primitive used for fork/join parallelism. We create a latch with a count of N; threads then signal the latch, which decrements N by 1; other threads can wait on the latch at any point; when the latch count reaches 0, all threads are woken and subsequent waiters return without waiting.
The implementation internally lazily creates a true Win32 event as needed. We also use some amount of spinning on MP machines before falling back to a wait.

member.name: M:System.Threading.CountdownEvent.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new event.
member.param: The # of signals before the latch transitions to the signaled state
member.exception: If count is less than zero.

member.name: M:System.Threading.CountdownEvent.Dispose
member.summary: Gets rid of this latch's associated resources. This can consist of a Win32 event which is (lazily) allocated by the underlying thin event. This method is not safe to call concurrently -- i.e. a caller must coordinate to ensure only one thread is using the latch at the time of the call to Dispose.

member.name: M:System.Threading.CountdownEvent.Decrement
member.summary: Registers a signal with the event. If this transitions the current count to 0, the latch state is set to signaled and any waiting threads are woken up.
member.returns: True if the latch became signaled, false otherwise.
member.exception: If the latch is already signaled.
If the latch has been canceled.

member.name: M:System.Threading.CountdownEvent.Decrement(System.Int32)
member.summary: Registers a certain number of signals with the event. If this transitions the current count to 0, the latch state is set to signaled and any waiting threads are woken up.
member.param: The number of signals to register.
member.returns: True if the latch became signaled, false otherwise.
member.exception: If the latch is already signaled or the count specified would have brought the event's count below zero.
If the latch has been canceled.
If count is less than zero.

member.name: M:System.Threading.CountdownEvent.Reset
member.summary: Resets the current count back to the original count and ensures the underlying event has been reset. The new count is equal to the count supplied originally at construction time. This is unsafe to call concurrently.

member.exception: If the count is less than zero.

member.summary:
Performs the major work of the parallel for loop. It assumes that argument validation has already been performed by the caller. This function's whole purpose in life is to enable as much reuse of common implementation details for the various For overloads we offer. Without it, we'd end up with lots of duplicate code. It handles: (1) simple for loops, (2) for loops that depend on ParallelState, and (3) for loops with thread local data.
@TODO: at some point in the future, we may want to manually inline the interesting bits into the specific overloads above. There is some overhead associated with the extra arguments passed to the function, and various if-checks in the code. It is also more difficult to follow what the code does as-is because it has to handle the three flavors.
member.typeparam: The type of the local data.
member.param: The loop's start index, inclusive.
The loop's end index, exclusive.
The amount by which the loop index is advanced each iteration.
The simple loop body.
The loop body for ParallelState overloads.
The loop body for thread local state overloads.
A selector function that returns new thread local state.
A cleanup function to destroy thread local state.
member.remarks: Only one of the bodyXX arguments may be supplied (i.e. they are exclusive).

member.summary:
Performs the major work of the parallel foreach loop. It assumes that argument validation has already been performed by the caller. This function's whole purpose in life is to enable as much reuse of common implementation details for the various For overloads we offer. Without it, we'd end up with lots of duplicate code. member.name: T:System.Threading.AggregateException
member.summary: Represents multiple errors that occur during application execution.
member.remarks: is used to consolidate multiple failures into a single, throwable exception object, for cases where multiple exceptions may happen in parallel. While may be instantiated by user code, the need to do so is rare, as instances of are generated internally by the system.

member.name: T:System.Threading.SlimManualResetEvent
member.summary:
SlimManualResetEvent wraps a manual-reset event internally with a little bit of spinning. When an event will be set imminently, it is often advantageous to avoid a 4k+ cycle context switch in favor of briefly spinning. Therefore we layer on to a brief amount of spinning that should, on the average, make using the slim event cheaper than using Win32 events directly. This can be reset manually, much like a Win32 manual-reset would be.
Notes: We lazily allocate the Win32 event internally. Therefore, the caller should always call Dispose to clean it up, just in case. This API is a no-op of the event wasn't allocated, but if it was, ensures that the event goes away eagerly, instead of waiting for finalization.

member.name: T:System.Threading.SpinWait
member.summary:
ThinSpinWait is just a little value type that encapsulates some common spinning logic. It ensures we always yield on single-proc machines (instead of using busy waits), and that we work well on HT. It encapsulates a good mixture of spinning and real yielding. It's a value type so that various areas of the engine can use one by allocating it on the stack w/out unnecessary GC allocation overhead, e.g.:
void f() { SpinWait wait = new SpinWait(); while (!p) { wait.Spin(); } ... }
Internally it just maintains a counter that is used to decide when to yield, etc.
Assumptions: The caller should keep track of the 'Count', i.e. how many times Spin has been called, and responsibly fall back to a true wait after a while. The threshold should be smaller for single-proc machines, since each call to Spin yields.
Notes: We currently P/Invoke to SwitchToThread which is unsafe in a hosted CLR. Ideally one day the CLR will expose an API that does this. We want to avoid calling Sleep, because it's (a) expensive, and (b) can lead to starvation due to thread priorities, requiring that we do VERY expensive Sleep(1) calls.

member.name: M:System.Threading.SpinWait.Spin
member.summary: Performs a single Spin iteration. This is typically called in a loop, and does some- thing special depending on the number of times a Spin has been issued so far. For example, every so often it will Yield instead of busy spinning.

member.name: M:System.Threading.SpinWait.Reset
member.summary: Resets the internal spin counter. This makes the Spin API behave as though the next call were its first. If a SpinWait object is reused many times, you will want to reset it to avoid accidentally yielding too soon, etc.

member.name: P:System.Threading.SpinWait.Count
member.summary: Retrieves the number of times we've spun.

member.name: T:System.Threading.Tasks.TakeQueue`1
member.summary: A take queue is a concurrent queue where one thread can Push and Pop elements, and other threads can Take elements from the other end of the queue. If there are enough elements, pushing and popping can be done lock free and is extremely fast.
member.remarks:
The queue is implemented as an array. The head and tail index this array. To avoid copying elements, the head and tail index the array modulo the size of the array. By making this a power of two, we can use a cheap bit-and operation to take the modulus. The "mask" is always equal to the size of the task array minus one (where the size is a power of two).
The head and tail are volatile as they can be updated from different OS threads. The "head" is only updated by foreign threads as they Take (steal) a task from this queue. By putting a lock in Take, there is at most one foreign thread changing head at a time. The tail is only updated by the owning thread during Push or Pop.
invariants: elems.length is a power of 2 mask == tasks.length-1 head is only written to by threads calling Take tail is only written to by the owning thread, in Push and Pop At most one foreign thread can do a Take All methods except Take are executed from a single owning thread tail points to the first unused location, thus if head==tail, the queue is empty.

member.remarks: The default is implicitly used for scheduling tasks when no is specified explicitly or when is the default . This property will never return null (Nothing in Visual Basic). member.name: P:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskManager.Current
member.summary: Gets the current .
member.remarks: represents the that will be used to start a task if no has been specified explicitly. will return the used to start the nearest in the logical call chain. As an example, if task T1 was started with M1, and if task T1 then started task T2 without explicitly specifying a , T2 would implicitly run with M1. Similarly, if task T2 started task T3 without specifying a , T3 would run with M1. However, if T3 then started task T4 with M2, and T4 started task T5 without explicitly specifying a , T5 would run with M2 rather than with M1. Note that if would otherwise be unspecified, it will return . As such, will always return a valid .

member.name: T:System.Threading.Tasks.Worker
member.summary: A worker is an abstraction a control stack.
member.remarks: A worker can execute tasks. Since the CLR does not allow us to manipulate control stacks as such, we implement workers by associating them with a thread. This is more heavy weight but in practice we perform well. Workers are part of a , in each group, only one worker executes while others are blocked. Since only one worker executes, the task queue is shared by all workers inside a group. The idea is that groups improve thread locality, where we try to associate one group per core.

member.name: P:System.Threading.Tasks.Future`1.Value
member.summary: Gets or sets the value of this .
member.remarks: The get accessor for this property calls to ensure the asynchronous computation is complete before returning. Once the result of the computation is available, it is stored and will be returned immediately on later calls to . If the was provided with a when created, the property can only be set internally by the , any attempts to set it manually will result in an exception. Conversely, a created without a can only be set manually, and it can only be set once. Attempting to set such an instance's property multiple times will result in an exception.

member.name: T:System.Threading.Tasks.Future
member.summary: A factory class used to create instances of .
member.remarks: provides Create methods as does . However, supports type inferencing in languages like C#. For example, with it is possible to write: var f = Future.Create(() => g()); The C# compiler will infer the type argument to the factory method by inspecting the return value of the method g. member.name: M:System.Linq.IParallelEnumerable`1.GetEnumerator(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Overload that allows developers to request or supress pipelining explicitly. The default behaviour if not using this overload is to use pipelining. Use pipelining when following a query with foreach to execute the foreach on a separate thread as the query when elements become available. Supressing pipelining will force the system to use all available resources processing the query to completion before executing the foreach loop.
member.param: Set to true to request pipelining.
member.returns: An IEnumerator that turns on pipelining in parallel execution.

member.name: T:System.Linq.ParallelQuery
member.summary: This class adds static extension methods to IEnumerable to faciliate using Parallel LINQ to Objects with LINQ to objects. Primarily, this class adds AsParallel() methods which convert IEnumerable to IParallelEnumerable and an AsSequential() method to convert IParallelEnumerable to IEnumerable.

member.name: M:System.Linq.ParallelQuery.AsParallel``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: This is the method to opt into Parallel LINQ. This method takes no parameters and would set the existing parameters to default. This will not preserve the input order in the output and will use the maximum available hardware threads.
member.remarks:
AsParallel() Persists - Operators that bind to IParallelEnumerable return IParallelEnumberables with the same settings as the original IParallelEnumerable.
So, in the expression: var q = elements.AsParallel(optionsA, 4).Where(...)....Select(...) q will behave as if it has optionsA and degree of parallelism (DOP) 4.
Chained AsParallel()s - Aside from the vanilla AsParallel() calls that apply default settings to the IParallelEnumerable, there are other overrides that allow the developer to apply specific options for fine-grained control. It is important to understand how these options play together.
Rule 1 -Vanilla AsParallel() always returns an IParallelEnumerable with default options and DOP. Rule 2 DOP-applying AsParallel() override previous DOPs. Rule 3 - Options-Applying AsParallel() overrides previous Options. Rule 4 DOP and Options are independent. These Rules apply together, too.
First Input Wins - Some expressions will have operators with 2 IEnumerable inputs, such as Join, Union, etc. In these cases, the First inputs settings are used and the Second inputs settings are ignored.
member.typeparam: The type of elements of source.
member.param: An IEnumerable to convert to an IParallelEnumerable.
member.returns: The source as an IParallelEnumerable to bind to ParallelEnumerable extension methods.
